monthly_spend_analysis_data.ai_summary: Your total income for January was $3,750, and your total spending was $2,147.47, which is 57.3% of your income. The largest expense category was rent and utilities at $1,650 (44% of income). Food expenses were $138.49 (3.7% of income), transportation was $65 (1.7% of income), and entertainment was $45.99 (1.2% of income). To optimize your budget, consider reducing discretionary spending on entertainment and dining out. Additionally, explore ways to lower your housing and utility costs. With your retirement goal in mind, consider investing a portion of your income into a retirement account.

In February 2023, your total income was $3,250, and your total spending was $523.46, which is around 16% of your income. Your major expenses were insurance ($150), clothing ($75.5), electronics ($89.99), and gas ($32). While your spending on essentials like groceries and restaurants was reasonable, you could optimize your budget by reducing discretionary expenses on entertainment, clothing, and electronics. Consider setting a monthly budget and sticking to it to better align your spending with your retirement goals.

Your total income for March was $3,750, and your total spending was $807.47 (21.5% of income). The largest expense categories were Transportation ($120, 3.2%), General Services ($150, 4%), and Food ($111.99, 3%). To optimize your budget, consider reducing discretionary spending on clothing, electronics, and dining out. Additionally, allocating more funds towards retirement savings would help achieve your financial goal of planning for retirement.

Your total income for April was $3,750, and your total spending was $769.78, which is around 20.5% of your income. The largest expense category was Food at $193.31 (5.2% of income), followed by Transportation at $65 (1.7% of income), and Entertainment at $60.98 (1.6% of income). You also made a $150 transfer to your savings account and paid $200 towards your credit card bill. Overall, your spending seems reasonable, but you could consider reducing discretionary expenses like dining out and entertainment to boost your savings further for retirement.

In May 2023, your total income was $3,750, and your total spending was $807.47, which is 21.5% of your income. Your major expenses were Transportation ($120), General Services ($150), and Transfer to Savings ($200). While saving is good, you may want to review your insurance and transportation costs for potential savings. Additionally, consider reducing discretionary spending on categories like Clothing, Restaurants, and Electronics to better align with your retirement goal.

In June 2023, your total income was $3,750, and your total spending was $2,147.47, which is 57.3% of your income. Your largest expenses were rent ($1,500), internet/cable ($150), and groceries ($125.5). To optimize your budget, consider reducing discretionary spending on clothing, entertainment, and dining out. Additionally, explore cost-saving options for essential expenses like rent and utilities. Maintaining a balanced budget will help you achieve your retirement goals.

email_notifications.spending_summary_email: Your Monthly Financial Insights Are Ready!
email_notifications.coupons_email: Mary, you deserve to treat yourself! How about 20% off at Bed Bath & Beyond with code HOME20NOW? Spruce up your home decor and save big before 10/15.
email_notifications.loans_email: Retirement funds running low, Mary? Chase has personal loans from $3K-$35K at rates as low as 6.99% APR. Unlock that extra cash for life's adventures!
email_notifications.credit_cards_email: Level up your travel game with the Chase Sapphire Preferred, Mary! Earn 60K bonus points, get 2X points on travel/dining, and enjoy perks galore for $95/year.
email_notifications.savings_email: Mary, your retirement savings could use a boost! Why not open an Ally Premium Yield account earning 4.35% APY? No fees, easy mobile access - just pure growth!
